all right so sandeep you're first up we've been working together on connected mobility solutions since
you joined and you know we've done a lot of work together but what you consider
uh if you consider the massive amounts of data and the complexity of dealing with real-time data streams
what does a connected vehicle or mobility platform look like that's a great question dean you can
think of connected mobility technology stack as a three-tier stack
first there is the vehicle side which is where the data is actually created from the hundreds of different sensors
or cameras that are there in the vehicle which then gets published to the cloud over a regular
uh 4g cellular network using standard protocols
once the data comes into the cloud we have processing in the business layer this is where the data is ingested
processed transformed and stored and our third layer is our consumption layer which is the
apis where you serve this vehicle data and the outcomes from advanced analytics
that have been carried out the apis are key for the mobility solutions
and so this is where if you are an oem or a partner a supplier a startup you can develop
your monetization strategies through these apis and expose them to
your customers aws has also published a connected mobility reference architecture
which can allow you to rapidly develop your connected platform yeah that's
really interesting uh really really interesting this api based approach a really important step
to standardize the communication among all these components sensors and data but let's talk about the
customers and their issues their problems right some of the most valuable information our customers want
to hear typically relates to the challenges you face in building up these systems
building up these projects so what can you tell us about those and how did you overcome them
absolutely when you have millions of connected vehicles where each vehicle is capable of
generating billions of data points from their sensors every month you can just be paralyzed by
the sheer volume of data that needs to be ingested and so the challenges really fall into
three different categories one how do you ingest this vast amount of data
terabytes and terabytes in real time two how do you scale and how do you
process such a large amount of data uh real time and then third is you want
to be able to develop a platform that can serve billions of apis that
allow you to monetize your investment in the data the good news here is that
we have worked with multiple customers and help them overcome these challenges
and we can help you provide prescriptive guidance to accelerate the development uh efforts
of our customers so good points to mention uh cintiq
but you know when we embark on some of these large technology projects we always like to kind of
set up a set of principles to kind of guide our architectural decisions along the way so you know when you are approaching
these kinds of projects you know how do you think about it and what are some of the uh you know guiding principles that you
look to that's fantastic because we always work
backwards from our customers and different customers have different guiding principles
for what i have seen after working with several customers is that three of these principles
typically bubble up to the top the first guiding principle is generally around scalability
customers want to develop platforms that are highly scalable so that they can scale from a few
vehicles to tens of millions of vehicles and for this customers can leverage kinesis data
streams elastic mapreduce lambda dynamodb and several other aws
services that allow you to scale seamlessly the second guiding principle is around
resiliency nobody likes downtime and resiliency needs to be baked
into the design and here again with aws we have several out-of-the-box
capabilities such as s3 which is 11 9's of durability we have dynamo global tables where you
can have active active across regions and we can also leverage the concept of multiple availability
zones within a region so that if one zone went down you could continue to operate
without being interrupted and last but not least when you have data of such a
large magnitude cost becomes an important consideration and an important principle and so your
and so customers are looking to increase or decrease capacity elastically
as needed and only pay for what they consume and this is where the serverless pattern
fits in very beautifully now while all these principles are important
we should not forget that security is job zero and it's also job zero for our customers
so we provide capabilities to ensure that all data can be encrypted during transit
as well as when it is stored to make sure that nobody can access data without having
the right privileges yeah really important principles and
thinking applying this principle from few vehicles to millions that's really you know how you scale
right so that that's really impressive so one of the most important components
in this connected platform to me seems to be the data lake right so if you were to think about the data
pipelines as we call them the flow of information coming into the cloud platform
what are the major functional areas in the solution yeah and i think
when when folks talk about data lakes um sometimes it can be scary but in reality um data lakes you know
the fairly traditional pattern we have four functional areas in a data lake
there is ingest decode transform and consume and let me
describe these layers uh you know in a little bit of detail in the ingest here what's happening is that
the real-time data that is that is coming in from millions of connected vehicles
is ingested through arkanis's data streaming service and stored in a raw s3 bucket
once we ingest the data the next step is to decode the data because what happens is you've got raw
binary encoded data which is just about a few kilobytes uh collected you know multiple sent
sensors but then after decoding we make this available in a json format typically
which makes it easy for querying and aggregation
once your data is decoded then we go through a transformation phase and during this data during this phase
the data is aggregated it is cleansed it is transformed and it's made available for a variety of
different use cases those use cases could vary from batch processing machine learning setting up analytics
data sets and also making them available for real-time use for the apis that are that are exposed
and finally the last layer and the most important layer is the consumption layer and this is the
layer where we expose the data through apis real time so that our customers can
benefit from this real-time data
thanks sandeep for the overview on the data lake architecture so why don't we switch to srikanth so as

the cloud so we need to derive uh real-time business value from the data coming from these
connected vehicles so connected data lakes are real-time in nature and hence we are
using real-time streaming services like kinesis to populate the data lake and make the

associated can can range from 1x to 10x where we receive 10 times volume during peak

our customers automatically saw a five to ten percent decrease in their compute cost and and they were

aws gives a aws gives customers a variety of proactive tools and we'll
talk about you know three different levels that are available for cost management these include reserved instances
spot instances and then serverless architectures and then depending upon the workloads i
have seen customers leverage one of them some of them or all of them
when you have workloads like databases that run seven by 24 uh in in
in an rds type setup then reserved instances are your friends
they can give you up to 60 savings over a three year term if you're running jobs using the hadoop
framework using our elastic mapreduce where you need hundreds of processing nodes
but for a short duration say one hour say for a short duration of one to two hours
then the spot instances which can provide up to eighty percent savings
can come in really really handy and i've seen a lot of customers who are able to reduce
um their costs by leveraging spot instances and then when loads fluctuate like
srikant mentioned earlier from going from 1x to 10x during the day
during peak traffic it's best to keep that portion of the architecture elastic and serverless so it can grow and shrink
and you only pay for what you consume but on top of all of this we also have
